column2: Of the son, "Young Matt," the people called him, it is enough to say that he seemed made of the same metal and cast in the same mold as the father; a mighty frame, softened yet by young manhood's grace; a powerful neck and well poised head with wavy red-brown hair; and blue eyes that had in them the calm of summer skies or the glint of battle steel.

column2: Miss Sammy Lane was one of those rare young women whose appearance is not to be described.

column2: One can, of course, put it down that she was tall; beautifully tall, with the trimness of a young pine, deep bosomed, with limbs full-rounded, fairly tingling with the life and strength of perfect womanhood; and it may be said that her face was a face to go with one through the years, and to live still in one's dreams when the sap of life is gone, and, withered and old, one sits shaking before the fire; a generous, loving mouth, red lipped, full arched, with the corners tucked in and perfect teeth between; a womanly chin and nose, with character enough to save them from being pretty; hair dark, showing a touch of gold with umber in the shadows; a brow, full broad, set over brown eyes that had never been taught to hide behind their fringed veils, but looked always square out at you with a healthy look of good comradeship, a gleam of mirth, or a sudden, wide, questioning gaze that revealed depth of soul within.

column3: mr Howitt was wondering what staying at the ranch nights could have to do with the difficulty, when, up from the valley below, from out the darkness and the mists, came a strange sound; a sound as if someone were singing a song without words.

column2: So wild and weird was the melody; so passionately sweet the voice, it seemed impossible that the music should come from human lips.
column3: So wild and weird was the melody; so passionately sweet the voice, it seemed impossible that the music should come from human lips.

column2: It was more as though some genie of the forest-clad hills wandered through the mists, singing as he went with the joy of his possessions.
column3: It was more as though some genie of the forest clad hills wandered through the mists, singing as he went with the joy of his possessions.

column2: Mrs. Matthews came close to her husband's side, and placed her hand upon his shoulder as he half rose from his chair, his pipe fallen to the floor.
column3: mrs Matthews came close to her husband's side, and placed her hand upon his shoulder as he half rose from his chair, his pipe fallen to the floor.

column2: Young Matt rose to his feet and moved closer to the girl, who was also standing.
column3: Young Matt rose to his feet and moved closer to the girl, who was also standing.

column2: The stranger alone kept his seat and he noted the agitation of the others in wonder.
column3: The stranger alone kept his seat and he noted the agitation of the others in wonder.

column2: For some moments the sound continued, now soft and low, with the sweet sadness of the wind in the pines; then clear and ringing, it echoed and reechoed along the mountain; now pleadings, as though a soul in darkness prayed a gleam of light; again rising, swelling exultingly, as in glad triumph, only to die away once more to that moaning wail, seeming at last to lose itself in the mists.
column3: For some moments the sound continued, now soft and low, with the sweet sadness of the wind in the pines; then clear and ringing, it echoed and reechoed along the mountain; now pleadings, as though a soul in darkness prayed a gleam of light; again rising, swelling exultingly, as in glad triumph, only to die away once more to that moaning wail, seeming at last to lose itself in the mists.

column2: Slowly Old Matt sank back into his seat and the stranger heard him mutter, "Poor boy, poor boy." Aunt Mollie was weeping.
column3: Slowly Old Matt sank back into his seat and the stranger heard him mutter, "Poor boy, poor boy." Aunt Mollie was weeping.

column2: Suddenly Sammy sprang from the steps and running down the walk to the gate sent a clear, piercing call over the valley: "O--h--h, Pete." The group on the porch listened intently.
column3: Suddenly Sammy sprang from the steps and running down the walk to the gate sent a clear, piercing call over the valley: "O-h-h, Pete." The group on the porch listened intently.

column2: Again the girl called, and yet again: "O--h--h, Pete." But there was no answer.
column3: Again the girl called, and yet again: "O-h-h, Pete." But there was no answer.

column2: It's no use, honey, said Mrs. Matthews, breaking the silence; "it just ain't no use;" and the young girl came slowly back to the porch.
column3: It's no use, honey, said mrs Matthews, breaking the silence; "it just ain't no use;" and the young girl came slowly back to the porch.
